attributes.title: Replication of Gold (2008) "Unrealistic optimism and event threat"
attributes.description: The study will conceptually replicate Gold (2008) "Unrealistic optimism and event threat". Furthermore, I aim to replicate the interaction between the independent variables event threat (low vs. high) and question order (self-first vs. other-first) on the dependent variable difference score (self ratings - other ratings). The Replication will use the same event. Once I will use a different measurement (probability indication) and once the same scale (7-Point-Likert-Scale) as used in the original study. Although I use a different sample (non-student sample instead of student sample). Moreover there will be a measure of the desire for uniqueness and the perceived controllability at the end of the study.

item1.value:
In the original study Gold (2008) found that event threat has a different effect on unrealistic optimism depending on the threat (low vs. high) and the question order (Self-first: „What do you think is the likelihood that you will develop homocysteine-related heart problems later in life?’’ vs. other-first: ‘‘What do you think is the likelihood that the average Deakin University student will develop homocysteine-related heart problems later in life?’’). He used a 2 (event threat: high vs. low) × 2 (question order: self-first vs. other-first) between group design to find an effect of event threat on unrealistic optimism. 
The aim of this study is to replicate the findings (a,b) of unrealistic optimism which has been originally found by Gold (2008). Additionally the findings (c,d,e) also found by the author will be examined and the effects (f,g) will be explored. To find these effects, I am going to run a direct and a conceptual replication. Even though I expect to find the same effects in both replications there should be a difference in the effect size between the two (h).

a)	The difference score (DS) calculated by the likelihood estimation for the self (SE) minus the likelihood estimation for others (OE) (DS = SE – OE = DS) will be positive for the whole sample and significantly deviate from 0. In other words, the participants will rate their own risk to develop homocysteine-related heart problems as lower as the risk for the average other (same sex and same age).
b)	The event threat manipulation (low vs. high) and the question order manipulation (self-first vs. other-first) will interact significantly. In other words, event threat will have a different effect on the DS depending on the question order.
c)	The DS will be greater for the event-threat-high groups than for event-threat-low groups, although this effect will be stronger for the self-first group.
d)	The question order (self- first vs. other-first) will lead to a higher DS for the other-first group when the event threat is low but not when event threat is high.
e)	Comparing only the estimates which were given first will lead to lower estimates for the self than for other, although this effect will be stronger for the high event threat groups.
f)	The DS will correlate positively with the perceived controllability scale.
g)	The DS will correlate positively with the personal sense of uniqueness (PSU) scale.
h)	The interaction effect will be smaller for the conceptual replication than for the direct replication and original study.

item2.value: There is still a lack of research on unrealistic optimism and the question order effect even though it would have important implications for the field of research. Although the scale (7-Point-Likert) which is used in the original study is found to produce unrealistic optimism by itself, so it is important to take a look at the effect with a different kind of scale (probability indication) and compare the effect size found with the 7-Point-Likert-Scale and probability indication.

item3.value: ANOVA: IV1) event threat (low vs. high); between x IV2) question order (self-first vs. other-first); between,  DV:  Difference Score (= self-ratings – other-ratings)  effects: no main effect, but interaction effect (F(1,144) = 10.12, p = .002 (Ƞp^2  = .0657)). Regarding the interaction effect, in line with Gold (2008), the high threat condition should lead to higher DS’s than the low threat condition although this effect should be stronger in the self-first condition than in the other-first condition.   Additional effects found in the original study: Difference Score of the whole sample: t-Test (deviation from 0) M = .09, SD = 1.48; t(147) = 7,39, p < 0.001 (Ƞp^2 = .2722)

item4.value: 90% CI for Ƞp^2  = .0657: Lower limit: Ƞ_p^2  = 0,0152229 ; Upper limit: Ƞ_p^2  = 0,1387198.  Calculated with Uanhoro, J. O. (2017). Effect size calculators. Retrieved February 11, 2020 from: https://effect-size-calculator.herokuapp.com/

item6.value: Paper and pencil in the Deakin University. It is not reported more specific in the paper.

item11.value: It is not sure if the event (homocysteine-related heart problems) used in the original paper is unknown for the sample of the replication. Everything else should hold, because it is the same procedure.

item12.value: The experimenter will be at home, because the data is collected with an online questionnaire.

item13.value: The experimenter will not know about the participants experimental condition

item14.value: The experimenter knows about the hypotheses.

item16.value: To have 85% power for the main (event threat, question order) and interaction (event threat × question order × type of measure) effects given ƞp2 = 0.0657 with alpha = 0.05, I need 146 participants for each replication. As some participants also need to be excluded (see below), I start a HIT for 300 participants to have N = 150 for the direct and N =150 for the conceptual replication.

item24.value: The direct replication should not be influenced by anything other than the sample. The conceptual replication could be influenced by the different scale used to assess the difference score. Other studies have shown that the scale I am going to use in the replication study can decrease the effect because of a greater response range (Otten & van der Pligt, 1996).

item25.value: I will compare the effect size of the event threat (low vs. high) × question order (self-first vs. other first) interaction in the original study, direct replication study and conceptual replication study with an ANOVA. Moreover, I will compare the confidence interval of the effect size for all three studies.

item26.value: I will exclude everyone who indicates that we should not use the data at the end of the survey (Meade & Craig, 2012). Furthermore, I will exclude everyone who is aware of the unrealistic optimism effect and knows how it is calculated.

item27.value:
As in the original study the participants will be confronted with an information which describes an imaginary study result that can affect the life of the participants (getting homocysteine-related heart problems). For the half of the participants the study result will have a big effect and for the other half it will have a small effect on their own life. Having read this information participants are asked to estimate the probability to experience the study result first for them self (1) and then for another person of the same age and same sex (2). The question order will be reversed for half of the participants in each information group (high threat vs. low threat). 
I will run a 2 event threat (low vs. high) × 2 question order (self-first vs. other-first); between ANOVA for the direct replication and the same for the conceptual replication which will lead to 4 groups in each replication study.

Difference and similarities:
(1)	For the first study (direct replication) the measure (7-Point-Likert-Scale) will be the same as used in the original study.
(2)	For the second study (conceptual replication) the measure will have a different scale (Probabilty slider) as used in the original study.
(3)	The additional Measures (perceived control and personal sense of uniqueness) did not appear in the original study.

item28.value: Finding a significant event threat (low vs. high) × question order (self-first vs. other first) interaction with a comparable effect size between the original study (Gold, 2008) and the direct replication. Further there should be a significant event threat (low vs. high) × question order (self-first vs. other first) for the conceptual replication.

summary.value: This is an updated online appendix to 'Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of out-of-hours palliative care: a systematic review' [Johnston BM et al., HRB Open Research Version 1 published February 2020]. It differs from the prior registration because a new file (20200226...) has been added at editor insistence. It clarifies which section of the paper a PRISMA item is addressed in (as distinct from the page number of the original manuscript, which is provided in 20200220...).

attributes.title: Raw Data for Quercetin
attributes.description: This data is used for calculating quercetin content from wild mango

summary.value: The new findings in basic research on the potential of wild mangoes from the island of Sumatra as a source of antioxidant. This study aims to analyze the antioxidant profile and quantification of gallic acid and quercetin content from leaves and stem bark of Sumatran wild mangoes. Exploration and analysis of phytochemical constituents from 11 Sumatran wild mangoes. The quantitatively antioxidant activity test of wild mango with 1,1- diphenyl-2-picryl hydroxyl (DPPH), total flavonoid, and phenolic analysis, and determination of quercetin and gallic acid content by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) method.

attributes.title: Visualization pattern of the highly cited scientific output of Indian Physiotherapists: A bibliometric study

summary.value:
Background: Research in physiotherapy support the advancement in the evidence-based practice and development of a highly skilled workforce. This study aims to explore the visualization pattern of the highly cited scientific output of Indian physiotherapists from the year 1999 to 2018. 

Methods: A descriptive study design was adopted to understand the visualization pattern of the highly cited scientific output of Indian physiotherapists in the Web of Science database during the period from 1999 to 2018. A search was carried out using the following term "((TS=(physiotherapy) OR TS=("physical rehabilitation") OR TS=("physical therapy")) AND AD=(India))Indexes=SCI-EXPANDED, SSCI, A&HCI, CPCI-S, CPCI-SSH, ESCI, CCR-EXPANDED, IC Timespan=1999-2018. The secondary data collected were analyzed using the, Incites in Web of Science, and VOSviewer software tools. 

Results:  A total of 489 articles was published between the year 1999 and 2018, with a peak of 103 in 2016 and 2420 citations. A decline in publication count was observed after 2016. The journal named, “International Journal of Physiotherapy” published a high number of articles (n=35). Manipal University (n=26) is found to be an active organization for physiotherapy research in India. Indian physiotherapists published a high number of research articles in collaboration with the US authors (n=24).

Conclusion: There is an increasing trend in the scientific output of Indian physiotherapists for the past two decades; however, a decline is observed after 2016. It is suggested to expand the research collaborations across the globe and further improve their scientific output, which would earn a high number of citations. Future research should reveal the factors influencing the scientific production of Indian Physiotherapists and devise appropriate strategies to attain further improvement. 

Keywords: Bibliometric study, India, Physiotherapy, Scientific output

attributes.title: Pluralistic Rhetoric, Student Identity, and Meaning (Diss)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Mizzou Student Identity and Pluralistic Rhetorical Style, January, 2020

other.value:
We will test whether conservatism moderates the effect of condition on meaning in life and uncertainty, such that the effects of condition will be most pronounced for liberals. We will also test whether uncertainty will show moderated mediation, such as uncertainty will explain both the effect of condition and the condition X conservatism interaction. We will test this possibility using PROCESS Macro for SPSS. 

We also test for evidence of moderation by constructs reflecting epistemic aversion to uncertainty that are thought to be psychological antecedent’s of conservative ideology. If moderation is found, we expect the pattern will show that among those low in need for closure, personal need for structure, intolerance of uncertainty, and high open-minded thinking, non-pluralism will lead to especially high meaning in life and low uncertainty. If this pattern is found, we will also test whether uncertainty shows evidence of moderated mediation with these constructs.  For these, we will use the same procedure described above.


Additionally, we will include a measure of the facets of meaning at the end of the study. We expect the delay to be long enough such that condition will not affect them. We additionally do not expect condition to affect the moderators. Thus, we will conduct correlational analyses of the relationship between political ideology (conservatism, liberalism, right-wing authoritarianism) with the facets of meaning (significance, purpose, and coherence), as a function of the variables we included measuring aversion to uncertainty (intolerance of ambiguity, open minded thinking, preference for one right answer, personal need for structure, and intolerance of uncertainty).

sample.value: We will aim to recruit at least 400 participants ( 200 for each  condition), but will recruit more, if possible.

analyses.value: We will test for effects of condition on mood by submitting positive and negative affect to a T-test. We expect participants to report better mood in the pluralist condition. To test for condition effects on meaning and uncertainty, we will submit each to an ANCOVA, controlling for mood. We expect meaning will be lower and uncertainty will be higher in the pluralist condition. We will test for mediation of the manipulation effect on meaning in life by uncertainty using the PROCESS MACRO (model 4). We expect that the direct effect of condition on meaning will no longer be significant, and that the indirect effect through uncertainty will be significant.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who did not read the passage.

dependent.value:
MIL is the key dependent variable, and will be measured with the 5-item Presence of Meaning subscale of the Meaning in Life Questionnaire (Steger, Frazier, Oishi & Kaler, 2006). We will also measure positive and negative affect (PA; NA) with mood descriptors. Uncertainty will be measured with items adapted from The Uncertainty Response Scale- Emotional (Greco & Roger, 2007), and the Mischel Uncertainty Illness Scale (Mischel, 1981). The items are all presented below. We will also measure message agreement using a face-valid item. 

We will also measure a number of moderators. The primary moderator is conservatism, which will be measured using items adapted from the PEW research center measure of ideological consistency (Pew Research Center, 1994). We will also measure a number of constructs tapping cognitive aversion to uncertainty that are associated with conservatism, including the Intolerance of Ambiguity composite from the Need for Closure Scale (Kruglanski et al., 2013), The Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, (Carleton et al., 2010), the Active Open Minded Thinking Scale (Haran, Ritov, Mellers, 2013), and the Personal Need for Structure Scale (Neuberg & Newsom, 1992), right-wing authoritarianism (Mavor et al., 2012). 

Will will also measure preference for one right answer. For this measure, we compiled 10 items from the Dogmatism scale (Altemeyer, 2002), Active Open Minded thinking Scale (Haran, Ritov, Mellers, 2013), Intolerance for Ambiguity Scale (Bunder, 1962), the Social Conformity vs. Autonomy Scale (Feldman, 2003), the Epistemic Belief Inventory (Schraw et al., 2002), in addition to items we created for these purposes. These items, as well, appear in full below. 

We will also include a measure of the facets of meaning in life at the end of the study (George & Park, 2016). 
 
Preference One right answer 
Please indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with the following, using the scale below 
1	2	3	4	5	6	7
Strongly disagree						Strongly agree
The sooner we all acquire similar values and ideals, the better
I believe there is usually one right way of doing things
If two people are arguing about something, at least one of them must be wrong
There is usually one right answer to problems
If we cannot achieve agreement on our values we will never be able to keep this society together.
I tend to prefer having one right answer, rather than valuing a variety of approaches to an issue
An expert who doesn’t come up with a definite answer probably doesn’t know too much.
“Flexibility in thinking” is another name for being “wishy-washy”
Changing your mind is a sign of weakness.
 One should disregard evidence that conflicts with one’s established beliefs.


Items adapted from Uncertainty Response Scale and Mischel Uncertainty Illness Scale 
Uncertainty
Please respond to the following items using the scale below, based on how the passage made you feel 
1	2	3	4	5	6	7
Strongly Disagree						Strongly Agree 

Right now I feel uncertain
Currently, I’m not sure what to think is right 
At this moment, I don’t feel sure of what it means to be a Mizzou student 
Reading the passage made me feel uncertain about my own views 
I currently feel confused about Mizzou student identity

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 2 conditions. These will express pluralistic attitudes about what it means to be a Mizzou student either using pluralistic or non-pluralistic rhetorical style.

hypothesis.value: Exposure to pluralistic attitudes about Mizzou student identity expressed using pluralistic rhetorical style will lead to lower meaning in life than pluralistic attitudes about Mizzou identity expressed using non-pluralistic rhetorical style. Pluralistic rhetoric will also lead to higher perceptions of uncertainty, and controlling for uncertainty will wipe out the effect of condition on meaning in life.

We will also measure a number of constructs tapping cognitive aversion to uncertainty that are associated with conservatism, including the Intolerance of Ambiguity composite from the Need for Closure Scale (Kruglanski et al., 2013), The Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, (Carleton et al., 2010), the Active Open Minded Thinking Scale (Haran, Ritov, Mellers, 2013), and the Personal Need for Structure Scale (Neuberg & Newsom, 1992), right-wing authoritarianism (Mavor et al., 2012). 

Will will also measure preference for one right answer. For this measure, we compiled 10 items from the Dogmatism scale (Altemeyer, 2002), Active Open Minded thinking Scale (Haran, Ritov, Mellers, 2013), Intolerance for Ambiguity Scale (Bunder, 1962), the Social Conformity vs. Autonomy Scale (Feldman, 2003), the Epistemic Belief Inventory (Schraw et al., 2002), in addition to items we created for these purposes. These items, as well, appear in full below. 

We will also include a measure of the facets of meaning in life at the end of the study (George & Park, 2016). 
 
Preference One right answer 
Please indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with the following, using the scale below 
1	2	3	4	5	6	7
Strongly disagree						Strongly agree
The sooner we all acquire similar values and ideals, the better
I believe there is usually one right way of doing things
If two people are arguing about something, at least one of them must be wrong
There is usually one right answer to problems
If we cannot achieve agreement on our values we will never be able to keep this society together.
I tend to prefer having one right answer, rather than valuing a variety of approaches to an issue
An expert who doesn’t come up with a definite answer probably doesn’t know too much.
“Flexibility in thinking” is another name for being “wishy-washy”
Changing your mind is a sign of weakness.
 One should disregard evidence that conflicts with one’s established beliefs.


Items adapted from Uncertainty Response Scale and Mischel Uncertainty Illness Scale 
Uncertainty
Please respond to the following items using the scale below, based on how the passage made you feel 
1	2	3	4	5	6	7
Strongly Disagree						Strongly Agree 

Right now I feel uncertain
Currently, I’m not sure what to think is right 
At this moment, I don’t feel sure of what it means to be a Mizzou student 
Reading the passage made me feel uncertain about my own views 
I currently feel confused about Mizzou student identity
registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 2 conditions. These will express pluralistic attitudes about what it means to be a Mizzou student either using pluralistic or non-pluralistic rhetorical style.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Exposure to pluralistic attitudes about Mizzou student identity expressed using pluralistic rhetorical style will lead to lower meaning in life than pluralistic attitudes about Mizzou identity expressed using non-pluralistic rhetorical style. Pluralistic rhetoric will also lead to higher perceptions of uncertainty, and controlling for uncertainty will wipe out the effect of condition on meaning in life.

Participants will be recruited through social media platforms (e.g. Instagram, Reddit, Facebook, etc.) and Western University’s research participation pool . Participants from the social media platforms will be invited to participate in the study by completing the online survey for the chance of winning a $100 gift card; while undergraduate students from the university's research participation pool will be granted 0.5 credit for their participation.

question.value:
The outcome variable will be the emotional responses to the 13-item Feelings scale that is asked for the second time after exposure to the sexual media (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”). 
With the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media. 
Measures Used in the Study:
SOS items (original and new): The original 21-item SOS (Fisher et al., 1988) (e.g. Masturbation can be an exciting experience.) and the new 58-item SOS (current authors) (e.g. 4.	Receiving sexually suggestive texts and images from my boyfriend/girlfriend is very sexy.).
Sexual Arousal: A single item measure (e.g. “How arousing do you find the above picture?”).
Feelings Scale:13-item Feelings scale (Smeaton, & Byrne, 1998, p. 50) (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”).
Social Desirability: 10-item Social desirability scale (Strahan, Gerbasi, 1973) (e.g. “I never resent being asked to return a favor”).
Revised Sociosexuality Inventory: 9-item Revised Sociosexuality Inventory (Penke & Asendorpf, 2008) (e.g. “Sex without love is OK.”).
Sexual Compulsivity Scale: 10-item Sexual Compulsivity Scale (Kalichman & Rompa, 2001) (e.g. “My sexual appetite has gotten in the way of my relationships”).
Double Standard Scale: 10-item Double Standard Scale (Caron, Davis, Halteman, Stickle, 1993) (e.g. “It is expected that a woman be less sexually experienced than her partner.”).
Sexual Health Survey: 4-item Sexual Health Survey (Eastman-Muller, Carr & Osterlind, 2006) will be assessed using of its knowledge subscale (e.g. “Women can become pregnant the first time they engage in vaginal-penile intercourse.”).
Measure of Sexual Identity Exploration and Commitment (Worthington, Navarro, Savoy & Hampton, 2008) will be captured using 6 items of the commitment subscale (e.g. “I know what my preferences are for expressing myself sexually.”) and 2 items sexual orientation (e.g. “My sexual orientation is clear to me.”). 
Brief Sensation Seeking Scale: 8-item Brief Sensation Seeking Scale (Hoyle, Stephenson, Palmgreen, Lorch, & Donohew, 2001) (e.g. “I prefer friends who are excitingly unpredictable.”). 
Religiosity: 3-item Religiosity scale (Hill & Hood,1999) (e.g. “How often do you attend religious services and activities?”).
Conservatism: 7-item Conservatism scale (Henningham, 1996) (e.g. agreeing or disagreeing with “Multiculturalism”). All the items that had sexual connotations (e.g. “Gay rights”) were removed from this scale.

To re-examine the validity of the SOS, we will be using a method of machine learning called random forest. This method has some advantages over the traditional regression models, including sensitivity to non-linear relationships, and testing for a wide range of predictors simultaneously while minimizing overfitting (Strobl, Malley, & Tutz, 2009; Liaw & Wiener, 2015; Joel, Eastwick & Finkel, 2017).

To control for social desirability, affective responses will first be regressed on social desirability. The residuals of this analysis will then be used as the outcome in the random forest model. Afterwards, with the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media.

The data cleaning, and regression analysis will be conducted in SPSS. We will then be using the VSURF (Variable Selection Using Random Forest) package for R to reduce the candidate predictor variables to a subset of variables that will be used in the final analysis. VSURF operates in three steps: 1) the threshold step, which removes variables that are not related to the outcome; 2) the moderate or interpretation step, which identifies all variables that are important for predicting the response variable (with some redundancy); and 3) the prediction step, which reduces the number of predictors further to lower redundancy in the predictors (Genuer, Poggi, & Tuleau-Malot, 2015).The predictors recommended by the interpretation step will be used to run the final random forest model. Total amount of variance predicted, the mean squared error, and the specific variables that emerged as predictors in their order of strength will then be reported and interpreted (Joel, Eastwick & Finkel, 2017).

To address all three goals of this study, we will retain original and new SOS items for further scrutiny if at least some of them are found to be among the best-predicting items for further scale validation. If all the best predicting items are not from these two sources, it would suggest that the SOS scale does not do what it is intended to do.

Provided that the predictive utility of the original and new SOS items is confirmed, we will conduct an exploratory factor analysis (EFA; maximum likelihood, parallel analysis + interpretability to identify the number of extracted factors; direct oblimin rotation to improve interpretation) on all of old and new SOS items that emerge from the interpretation step of VSURF procedure to examine construct validity. The goals of this EFA will be to: (1) clarify the underlying factor structure of these SOS items; (2) reduce the item pool by retaining only the 5 most highly loading items who’s pattern coefficients exceed .40 for each factor (high cross-loadings will not be used to disqualify items), and (3) identify interpretable factors that are poorly represented by the current item set (factors that are represented by fewer than 5 items that have pattern coefficients >.40). The results of this effort will then be used to guide a confirmatory factor analysis to determine the extent that such a model fits the data using typical cutoffs for fit indices. Additional conceptual dimensions may be identified at this stage if error covariances are needed to ensure acceptable model fit. If needed, a subsequent study may be conducted to validate additional items that may be needed to fill out poorly represented dimensions. If no additional items are needed, subsequent work will seek to confirm the factor structure by replicating the CFA model tested in the current study, establish evidence of convergent / divergent validity of the revised SOS scale and each of its sub-dimensions, and examine measurement invariance to determine the revised SOS represents and assesses the same concept across various groups (e.g. gender, sexual orientation).

Afterwards, with the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media.

The data cleaning, and regression analysis will be conducted in SPSS. We will then be using the VSURF (Variable Selection Using Random Forest) package for R to reduce the candidate predictor variables to a subset of variables that will be used in the final analysis. VSURF operates in three steps: 1) the threshold step, which removes variables that are not related to the outcome; 2) the moderate or interpretation step, which identifies all variables that are important for predicting the response variable (with some redundancy); and 3) the prediction step, which reduces the number of predictors further to lower redundancy in the predictors (Genuer, Poggi, & Tuleau-Malot, 2015).The predictors recommended by the interpretation step will be used to run the final random forest model. Total amount of variance predicted, the mean squared error, and the specific variables that emerged as predictors in their order of strength will then be reported and interpreted (Joel, Eastwick & Finkel, 2017).

To address all three goals of this study, we will retain original and new SOS items for further scrutiny if at least some of them are found to be among the best-predicting items for further scale validation. If all the best predicting items are not from these two sources, it would suggest that the SOS scale does not do what it is intended to do.

Provided that the predictive utility of the original and new SOS items is confirmed, we will conduct an exploratory factor analysis (EFA; maximum likelihood, parallel analysis + interpretability to identify the number of extracted factors; direct oblimin rotation to improve interpretation) on all of old and new SOS items that emerge from the interpretation step of VSURF procedure to examine construct validity. The goals of this EFA will be to: (1) clarify the underlying factor structure of these SOS items; (2) reduce the item pool by retaining only the 5 most highly loading items who’s pattern coefficients exceed .40 for each factor (high cross-loadings will not be used to disqualify items), and (3) identify interpretable factors that are poorly represented by the current item set (factors that are represented by fewer than 5 items that have pattern coefficients >.40). The results of this effort will then be used to guide a confirmatory factor analysis to determine the extent that such a model fits the data using typical cutoffs for fit indices. Additional conceptual dimensions may be identified at this stage if error covariances are needed to ensure acceptable model fit. If needed, a subsequent study may be conducted to validate additional items that may be needed to fill out poorly represented dimensions. If no additional items are needed, subsequent work will seek to confirm the factor structure by replicating the CFA model tested in the current study, establish evidence of convergent / divergent validity of the revised SOS scale and each of its sub-dimensions, and examine measurement invariance to determine the revised SOS represents and assesses the same concept across various groups (e.g. gender, sexual orientation).

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through social media platforms (e.g. Instagram, Reddit, Facebook, etc.) and Western University’s research participation pool . Participants from the social media platforms will be invited to participate in the study by completing the online survey for the chance of winning a $100 gift card; while undergraduate students from the university's research participation pool will be granted 0.5 credit for their participation. 
Individuals interested in joining the study must be at least 18 years of age, be able to read and respond to questions posed in English, and reside in Canada or the US.
Recruitment will be taking place between February 2020 - May 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size was set as 500 from both social media and university research pool. We will attempt to have up to 350 complete responses.

question.value:
The outcome variable will be the emotional responses to the 13-item Feelings scale that is asked for the second time after exposure to the sexual media (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”). 
With the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media. 
Measures Used in the Study:
SOS items (original and new): The original 21-item SOS (Fisher et al., 1988) (e.g. Masturbation can be an exciting experience.) and the new 58-item SOS (current authors) (e.g. 4.	Receiving sexually suggestive texts and images from my boyfriend/girlfriend is very sexy.).
Sexual Arousal: A single item measure (e.g. “How arousing do you find the above picture?”).
Feelings Scale:13-item Feelings scale (Smeaton, & Byrne, 1998, p. 50) (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”).
Social Desirability: 10-item Social desirability scale (Strahan, Gerbasi, 1973) (e.g. “I never resent being asked to return a favor”).
Revised Sociosexuality Inventory: 9-item Revised Sociosexuality Inventory (Penke & Asendorpf, 2008) (e.g. “Sex without love is OK.”).
Sexual Compulsivity Scale: 10-item Sexual Compulsivity Scale (Kalichman & Rompa, 2001) (e.g. “My sexual appetite has gotten in the way of my relationships”).
Double Standard Scale: 10-item Double Standard Scale (Caron, Davis, Halteman, Stickle, 1993) (e.g. “It is expected that a woman be less sexually experienced than her partner.”).
Sexual Health Survey: 4-item Sexual Health Survey (Eastman-Muller, Carr & Osterlind, 2006) will be assessed using of its knowledge subscale (e.g. “Women can become pregnant the first time they engage in vaginal-penile intercourse.”).
Measure of Sexual Identity Exploration and Commitment (Worthington, Navarro, Savoy & Hampton, 2008) will be captured using 6 items of the commitment subscale (e.g. “I know what my preferences are for expressing myself sexually.”) and 2 items sexual orientation (e.g. “My sexual orientation is clear to me.”). 
Brief Sensation Seeking Scale: 8-item Brief Sensation Seeking Scale (Hoyle, Stephenson, Palmgreen, Lorch, & Donohew, 2001) (e.g. “I prefer friends who are excitingly unpredictable.”). 
Religiosity: 3-item Religiosity scale (Hill & Hood,1999) (e.g. “How often do you attend religious services and activities?”).
Conservatism: 7-item Conservatism scale (Henningham, 1996) (e.g. agreeing or disagreeing with “Multiculturalism”). All the items that had sexual connotations (e.g. “Gay rights”) were removed from this scale.
